text: I chased upstairs. The corridor was eerily quiet. Her door wasn’t locked, as if she had known I would come.
"…Who are you, really? And why didn’t you step in back there?"
A faint sigh drifted from inside the room, like she was exhaling something that had been weighing on her chest.
"Who I am isn’t something you need to know right now."
"Then at least tell me this: why did you just watch while I was beaten? I saw your sword. Aren’t you a swordsman? Where was your responsibility?"
She stayed silent for two seconds, then said plainly, "Because I’m exhausted."
"It’s not that you weren’t worth saving. I just… couldn’t keep going."
The door opened a crack. She stood behind it, her face pale, dark circles heavy beneath her eyes as if she hadn’t slept for days. Yet the hand on her sword was still steady.
"I’ve dealt with things like this before. Over and over."
"But today, I don’t have the strength. If you want an explanation, this is it: I’m so tired that even lifting my hand hurts."
"…So you want me to understand you?"
"Yes." She nodded once. "You can blame me if you want, but don’t be reckless. If you had gone up against him tonight, you would have died."
"How do you know I would have died?"
"I’ve seen it," she said calmly. "That’s why I couldn’t be bothered to pretend this was our ‘first meeting.’"
"Listen. Don’t go out. Tonight is dangerous."
"You don’t need to understand the reason. You just need to do as I say."
Her tone wasn’t harsh—if anything, it was almost gentle, like she was leaving a way to survive for someone who didn’t know better.
"Go downstairs," she added. "Apply some medicine. Don’t push yourself."
The door closed slowly—not as a rejection meant to drive me away, but because she truly didn’t have the strength left to continue the conversation.
I stood in the corridor, realizing for the first time that her earlier coldness might not have been indifference—but exhaustion stretched to its breaking point.
